ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: office hours and occasionally conversation sectiom

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned so much about hindi, colloquial speaking, and important topics in India
Better Hindi conversation- very helpful in that regard. The teachers are nice and really care about you too. Not very different from Hindi I and II.
more grammar structures and practice with conversation
I improved my Hindi skills to be able to speak, read, and write at an intermediate level.
language speaking and listening skills, new hindi vocab, better at checking emails/staying updated with class because it is every day

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths
- Lots of help 
- Leniency with grading 
- They really want you to learn and encourage you to be curious 
- Ask you lots of questions in hindi so you get immersed in the language 

Weaknesses
- I think there some probably a lack of communication sometimes so, between the two professors, we were assigned a lot of work
- Sometimes, we focused on things like journals in class, which don't really help us learn

Weakness is a little too much homework- there were weekends where we have 5 assignments due on Monday. But the lecturers are very nice and are willing to accommodate. Strength is that the class felt really close and friendly.
The biggest strength of the course is the level of interaction with the professors. The weakness was online learning, but that could not be avoided this semester.

this class is pretty hard over zoom but more breakout rooms and engagement with students, letting us talk to each other more

the best thing is when we went over sentences together vs listened to lectures on grammar concepts

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: much harder to learn hindi over zoom.
The online lectures were very good, but creating a time for speaking practice specifically would have been helpful.
it could be made more clear that we have homework due and where to submit it

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: YES! Hindi is the best language you can take at Yale. The best professors who are funny, understanding, and encouraging.
I would recommend taking hindi to anyone interested in the language!
yes!!!! i love this language and the professors really show you that they care about what and who they are teaching
